posts.title: Why Axie Infinity is no Ponzi scheme
posts.content:
Blockchain-based game Axie Infinity has become a global phenomenon in a short span of time (this story goes into how it works and the details of its rise).

Since the game’s launch, many Filipinos have begun depending on their earnings from Axie Infinity to make ends meet. While it’s great that the game can be a source of income for so many who need it, this also comes with huge responsibilities.

In fact, many are worried that SkyMavis, the team behind Axie Infinity, may not be up to the task.

Image credit: Sky Mavis

The dreaded ‘P’ word

Progress is always a double-edged sword, and Axie Infinity’s play-to-earn model is not without its issues.

For one, some camps have asked if the game is a Ponzi scheme that exploits the economic troubles of developing countries like the Philippines.

They are worried that if their suspicions prove to be true, the scheme – as with others before it – will eventually unravel and take its players down with it.

Ponzi schemes, by definition, lack real products or assets.

Since many of Axie Infinity’s players simply cannot afford to lose, the question needs to be addressed.

So is it a Ponzi scheme? “This is a game that will constantly need new people streaming in by the droves,” an independent game developer from Singapore tells Tech in Asia. “The early settlers will earn the most, and those who are just coming in are the ones helping them to do so. This is exactly how a Ponzi scheme works, and I am very worried that those at the bottom will get burned,” adds the source, who declined to be named.

Ponzi schemes, by definition, lack real products or assets and simply pay existing investors using the money it gets from new investors.

Your view on Axie Infinity, therefore, hinges on whether you consider the game a real product, what you think of its future potential, and whether you think the intangible enjoyment that people derive from playing the game is of value.

One crucial question in this puzzle is what makes Smooth Love Potions (SLPs) – the in-game currency of Axie Infinity – valuable? To recap, SLPs are generated when existing players win a battle. They then use these tokens to breed new axies, the digital creatures that players battle with in the game.

Users will only have an incentive to breed axies, which are non-fungible tokens (NFTs), if more and more players want to buy and sell these creatures on the Axie Marketplace. This gives SLPs their value. As such, existing players are “paid,” and the tokens gain value through the money flowing in from new players.

Without more players and trading activity, there will be no demand for axies and no incentive to breed them, which means SLPs won’t be worth much.

Image credit: Timmy Loen

It’s no wonder that the nature of Axie Infinity’s in-game economic model has drawn comparisons to a Ponzi scheme.

However, there are two counter-arguments:

  • NFTs have inherent value
  • SLPs could become more useful

NFTs have inherent value

As easy as it is to dismiss NFTs as a mere gimmick, many do ascribe value (and quite a bit of it) to these digital assets. Like art pieces in the physical world, NFTs can be valuable as long as people are willing to pay a huge sum for the emotional satisfaction of owning them.

In March 2021, the digital artist Beeple sold his artwork to a Singaporean investor for US$69 million. Prior to that, many well-known internet memes like the Disaster Girl and Overly Attached Girlfriend also managed to fetch high prices as NFTs.

The Disaster Girl NFT that sold for 180 ether (roughly US$414,000 at the time) / Photo credit: Foundation.app

“NFTs are valuable because they grant you exclusive ownership over items that you otherwise cannot get access to,” says Miggy Azurin, a veteran Axie Infinity player and YouTuber. “In having these items, you have bragging rights,” he says, adding that people are willing to pay a premium for this privilege.

Setting aside the supply and demand of SLP tokens and axies, people are also attached to the game, the axies they own, and the community they’re involved in. It has become a part of their identity, and that’s worth something.

SLPs could become more useful

Even if we accept that Axie Infinity is a real game, some might find it hard to come to terms with the current sky-high value of SLP tokens and NFTs in general.

This is where we enter subjective territory.

Due to how big the game has become, it is too easy to forget that Axie Infinity is still very much in its infancy and has a lot more room to evolve.

The game remains intimidating to those who lack knowledge of how cryptocurrency works, which is the majority of people in the world.

It’s not something you can immediately pick up and play – you’d need to fork out over a thousand US dollars to buy competitive axies, or get managers to rent you some. These barriers can be overcome, but only if you’re serious about making money from it.

“While the peoples’ fears are understandable, I hope they also understand that there are many things going on behind the scenes,” Aleksander Larsen, co-founder and chief operating officer of SkyMavis, tells Tech in Asia. “Most of these scenarios that people worry about – rest assured that the team has thought of it and has plans in store to deal with them.”

Aleksander Larsen, co-founder and COO of SkyMavis / Photo credit: Aleksander Larsen

Gabby Dizon, co-founder of Yield Guild Games, echoes Larsen’s sentiments. “Axie Infinity has barely just begun. There is a long way to go, and I think people must be patient. There is so much room for growth, and the potential upsides are crazy to think about.”

While it is true that the value of SLP tokens in this current version of the game may be chiefly tied to newer players coming in and thus poses a problem to Axie Infinity‘s in-game economy, it would be a stretch to call the game a Ponzi scheme. Getting new players in is not the only way to boost the value of SLPs.

As the game develops, SLPs could gain more utility. As it stands, Axie Infinity is a full-featured, skill-based game with an active marketplace. So the product is real and is set to grow.

One widely anticipated move for Axie Infinity is the launch of a “land gameplay” feature in which players can own and develop virtual land, fight off creatures for rewards, and cultivate resources. It’s set to debut in fourth quarter of this year.

While the exact impact of land gameplay isn’t clear, it will certainly diversify the game’s economy and possibly increase trading activity – not to mention make it more fun.

A plot of land in Axie Infinity / Image credit: Sky Mavis

Final thoughts

In contrast to Ponzi schemes that usually require a lot of hard-sell tactics to get recruits, there may not be a need to worry about new players coming into Axie Infinity.

Filipino players Servillo and Verginia Enriquez encapsulate this point perfectly. The elderly couple saw their wages drastically reduced amid the pandemic and now rely heavily on Axie Infinity to pay for their medication.

For the past month, the number of daily average users in the game has increased significantly, from around 100,000 players in the first week of June 2021 to around 800,000 players in late July.

This trend will continue for as long as there are those who depend on games like Axie Infinity to survive. With players enrolling in the Axie Scholarship Program – where players sponsor users who can’t afford their own axies – to play the game, demand for axies and SLP tokens will likely be constant. If this cycle doesn’t change, SLPs will not lose their value.

Having addressed doubts that Axie Infinity is a Ponzi scheme, we’ll turn to the real issues plaguing the game in the next story. Stay tuned.

This is the second installment of a three-part series. Read part one here.
posts.excerpt: The sky-high value of its tokens might seem mind-boggling, but that doesn’t mean it’s a scam.

author.description: Full-time Blockchain, Cryptocurrencies and Tech nerd

posts.editor: Editing by Terence Lee and Jaclyn Tiu

seo.title: Why Axie Infinity is no Ponzi scheme
seo.description: The sky-high value of its tokens might seem mind-boggling, but that doesn’t mean it’s a scam.
